speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates; tis Gloucester that calls.

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: [Within]  Whos there that knocks so imperiously?

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: First Serving-ManIt is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

speaker: Second Warder
text_entry: [Within]  Whoeer he be, you may not be let in.

speaker: Second Warder
text_entry: First Serving-ManVillains, answer you so the lord protector?

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: [Within]  The Lord protect him! so we answer him:

speaker: First Warder
text_entry: We do no otherwise than we are willd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who willed you? or whose will stands but mine?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Theres none protector of the realm but I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Break up the gates, Ill be your warrantize.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Gloucesters men rush at the Tower Gates, and WOODVILE the Lieutenant speaks within

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: What noise is this? what traitors have we here?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates; heres Gloucester that would enter.

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: Have patience, noble duke; I may not open;

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: The Cardinal of Winchester forbids:

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: From him I have express commandment

speaker: WOODVILE
text_entry: That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Faint-hearted Woodvile, prizest him fore me?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom Henry, our late sovereign, neer could brook?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art no friend to God or to the king:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Open the gates, or Ill shut thee out shortly.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Serving-MenOpen the gates unto the lord protector,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or well burst them open, if that you come not quickly.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter to the Protector at the Tower Gates BISHOP OF WINCHESTER and his men in tawny coats

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: How now, ambitious Humphry! what means this?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Peeld priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: I do, thou most usurping proditor,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And not protector, of the king or realm.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou that contrivedst to murder our dead lord;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou that givest whores indulgences to sin:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill canvass thee in thy broad cardinals hat,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not slay thee, but Ill drive thee back:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy scarlet robes as a childs bearing-cloth

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill use to carry thee out of this place.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Do what thou darest; I beard thee to thy face.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What! am I dared and bearded to my face?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Draw, men, for all this privileged place;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Under my feet I stamp thy cardinals hat:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In spite of pope or dignities of church,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here by the cheeks Ill drag thee up and down.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the pope.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Winchester goose, I cry, a rope! a rope!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thee Ill chase hence, thou wolf in sheeps array.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Out, tawny coats! out, scarlet hypocrite!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here GLOUCESTERs men beat out BISHOP OF  WINCHESTERs men, and enter in the hurly- burly the Mayor of London and his Officers

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Fie, lords! that you, being supreme magistrates,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Peace, mayor! thou knowst little of my wrongs:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Heres Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath here distraind the Tower to his use.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Heres Gloucester, a foe to citizens,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: One that still motions war and never peace,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Oercharging your free purses with large fines,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: That seeks to overthrow religion,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Because he is protector of the realm,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And would have armour here out of the Tower,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To crown himself king and suppress the prince.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here they skirmish again

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: But to make open proclamation:

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Come, officer; as loud as eer thou canst,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Cry.

speaker: Officer
text_entry: All manner of men assembled here in arms this day

speaker: Officer
text_entry: against Gods peace and the kings, we charge and

speaker: Officer
text_entry: command you, in his highness name, to repair to

speaker: Officer
text_entry: your several dwelling-places; and not to wear,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger,

speaker: Officer
text_entry: henceforward, upon pain of death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cardinal, Ill be no breaker of the law:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But we shall meet, and break our minds at large.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, we will meet; to thy cost, be sure:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Thy heart-blood I will have for this days work.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Ill call for clubs, if you will not away.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: This cardinals more haughty than the devil.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Mayor, farewell: thou dost but what thou mayst.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: For I intend to have it ere long.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Exeunt, severally, GLOUCESTER and BISHOP OF WINCHESTER with their Serving-men

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: See the coast cleard, and then we will depart.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: I myself fight not once in forty year.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: SCENE IV. Orleans.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Enter, on the walls, a Master Gunner and his Boy

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Master-GunnerSirrah, thou knowst how Orleans is besieged,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And how the English have the suburbs won.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Howeer unfortunate I missd my aim.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Master-GunnerBut now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me:

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Chief master-gunner am I of this town;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Something I must do to procure me grace.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: The princes espials have informed me

speaker: Boy
text_entry: How the English, in the suburbs close intrenchd,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars

speaker: Boy
text_entry: In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And thence discover how with most advantage

speaker: Boy
text_entry: They may vex us with shot, or with assault.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: To intercept this inconvenience,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: A piece of ordnance gainst it I have placed;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And even these three days have I watchd,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: If I could see them.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: If thou spyst any, run and bring me word;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And thou shalt find me at the governors.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Father, I warrant you; take you no care;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Ill never trouble you, if I may spy them.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter, on the turrets, SALISBURY and TALBOT, GLANSDALE, GARGRAVE, and others

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Talbot, my life, my joy, again returnd!

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: How wert thou handled being prisoner?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Or by what means gotst thou to be released?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Discourse, I prithee, on this turrets top.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Calld the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For him was I exchanged and ransomed.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But with a baser man of arms by far

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Once in contempt they would have barterd me:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Which I, disdaining, scornd; and craved death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Rather than I would be so vile esteemd.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In fine, redeemd I was as I desired.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, O! the treacherous Fastolfe wounds my heart,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whom with my bare fists I would execute,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If I now had him brought into my power.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Yet tellst thou not how thou wert entertaind.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In open market-place produced they me,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To be a public spectacle to all:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here, said they, is the terror of the French,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The scarecrow that affrights our children so.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Then broke I from the officers that led me,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And with my nails diggd stones out of the ground,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To hurl at the beholders of my shame:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My grisly countenance made others fly;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: None durst come near for fear of sudden death.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In iron walls they deemd me not secure;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: So great fear of my name mongst them was spread,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That they supposed I could rend bars of steel,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And spurn in pieces posts of adamant:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That walked about me every minute-while;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And if I did but stir out of my bed,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter the Boy with a linstock

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But we will be revenged sufficiently

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Now it is supper-time in Orleans:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Here, through this grate, I count each one

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: and view the Frenchmen how they fortify:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Let me have your express opinions

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Where is best place to make our battery next.

speaker: GARGRAVE
text_entry: I think, at the north gate; for there stand lords.

speaker: GLANSDALE
text_entry: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For aught I see, this city must be famishd,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here they shoot. SALISBURY and GARGRAVE fall

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

speaker: GARGRAVE
text_entry: O Lord, have mercy on me, woful man!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What chance is this that suddenly hath crossd us?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How farest thou, mirror of all martial men?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: One of thy eyes and thy cheeks side struck off!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Accursed tower! accursed fatal hand

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That hath contrived this woful tragedy!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In thirteen battles Salisbury oercame;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Henry the Fifth he first traind to the wars;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His sword did neer leave striking in the field.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Yet livest thou, Salisbury? though thy speech doth fail,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: One eye thou hast, to look to heaven for grace:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Thou shalt not die whiles--

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: He beckons with his hand and smiles on me.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As who should say When I am dead and gone,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Remember to avenge me on the French.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Plantagenet, I will; and like thee, Nero,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wretched shall France be only in my name.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What stir is this? what tumults in the heavens?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle joind,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A holy prophetess new risen up,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here SALISBURY lifteth himself up and groans

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Frenchmen, Ill be a Salisbury to you:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pucelle or puzzel, dolphin or dogfish,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Your hearts Ill stamp out with my horses heels,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Convey me Salisbury into his tent,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And then well try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum. Exeunt

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE V. The same.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here an alarum again: and TALBOT pursueth the  DAUPHIN, and driveth him: then enter JOAN LA  PUCELLE, driving Englishmen before her, and exit after them then re-enter TALBOT

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A woman clad in armour chaseth them.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Re-enter JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here, here she comes. Ill have a bout with thee;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Devil or devils dam, Ill conjure thee:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And straightway give thy soul to him thou servest.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Come, come, tis only I that must disgrace thee.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here they fight

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My breast Ill burst with straining of my courage

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: They fight again

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Talbot, farewell; thy hour is not yet come:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I must go victual Orleans forthwith.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: A short alarum; then enter the town with soldiers

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Oertake me, if thou canst; I scorn thy strength.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Help Salisbury to make his testament:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This day is ours, as many more shall be.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: My thoughts are whirled like a potters wheel;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I know not where I am, nor what I do;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A witch, by fear, not force, like Hannibal,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Are from their hives and houses driven away.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: They calld us for our fierceness English dogs;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A short alarum

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Hark, countrymen! either renew the fight,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or tear the lions out of Englands coat;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions stead:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Or horse or oxen from the leopard,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Alarum. Here another skirmish

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It will not be: retire into your trenches:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You all consented unto Salisburys death,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Pucelle is enterd into Orleans,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: In spite of us or aught that we could do.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: O, would I were to die with Salisbury!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Exit TALBOT. Alarum; retreat; flourish

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter, on the walls, JOAN LA PUCELLE, CHARLES, REIGNIER, ALENCON, and Soldiers

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Advance our waving colours on the walls;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Rescued is Orleans from the English

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Thus Joan la Pucelle hath performd her word.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Divinest creature, Astraeas daughter,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: How shall I honour thee for this success?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thy promises are like Adonis gardens

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That one day bloomd and fruitful were the next.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Recoverd is the town of Orleans:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: More blessed hap did neer befall our state.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Why ring not out the bells aloud throughout the town?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And feast and banquet in the open streets,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: To celebrate the joy that God hath given us.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: All France will be replete with mirth and joy,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: When they shall hear how we have playd the men.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: For which I will divide my crown with her,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And all the priests and friars in my realm

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Shall in procession sing her endless praise.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: A statelier pyramis to her Ill rear

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Than Rhodopes or Memphis ever was:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: In memory of her when she is dead,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Her ashes, in an urn more precious

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Than the rich-jeweld of Darius,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Transported shall be at high festivals

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Before the kings and queens of France.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No longer on Saint Denis will we cry,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But Joan la Pucelle shall be Frances saint.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Come in, and let us banquet royally,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: After this golden day of victory.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE I. Before Orleans.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter a Sergeant of a band with two Sentinels

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant:

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: If any noise or soldier you perceive

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Near to the walls, by some apparent sign

speaker: Sergeant
text_entry: Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Sergeant, you shall.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Exit Sergeant

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Thus are poor servitors,

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: When others sleep upon their quiet beds,

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Constraind to watch in darkness, rain and cold.

speaker: First Sentinel
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, and Forces, with scaling-ladders, their drums beating a dead march

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: By whose approach the regions of Artois,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Wallon and Picardy are friends to us,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Having all day caroused and banqueted:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Embrace we then this opportunity

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: As fitting best to quittance their deceit

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Despairing of his own arms fortitude,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To join with witches and the help of hell!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Traitors have never other company.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: But whats that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A maid, they say.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: A maid! and be so martial!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: If underneath the standard of the French

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: She carry armour as she hath begun.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Well, let them practise and converse with spirits:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: God is our fortress, in whose conquering name

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Not all together: better far, I guess,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That we do make our entrance several ways;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That, if it chance the one of us do fail,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The other yet may rise against their force.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Agreed: Ill to yond corner.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And I to this.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Of English Henry, shall this night appear

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How much in duty I am bound to both.

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: Arm! arm! the enemy doth make assault!

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: Cry: St. George, A Talbot.

speaker: Sentinels
text_entry: The French leap over the walls in their shirts.  Enter, several ways, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, half ready, and half unready

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: How now, my lords! what, all unready so?

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Unready! ay, and glad we scaped so well.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Hearing alarums at our chamber-doors.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Of all exploits since first I followd arms,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Neer heard I of a warlike enterprise

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: More venturous or desperate than this.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: If not of hell, the heavens, sure, favour him.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Here cometh Charles: I marvel how he sped.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Enter CHARLES and JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Make us partakers of a little gain,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That now our loss might be ten times so much?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: At all times will you have my power alike?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Sleeping or waking must I still prevail,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This sudden mischief never could have falln.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Duke of Alencon, this was your default,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: That, being captain of the watch to-night,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Did look no better to that weighty charge.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Had all your quarters been as safely kept

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: As that whereof I had the government,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Mine was secure.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And so was mine, my lord.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And, for myself, most part of all this night,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Within her quarter and mine own precinct

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: I was employd in passing to and fro,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: About relieving of the sentinels:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Then how or which way should they first break in?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Question, my lords, no further of the case,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: How or which way: tis sure they found some place

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And now there rests no other shift but this;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To gather our soldiers, scatterd and dispersed,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And lay new platforms to endamage them.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier, crying A  Talbot! a Talbot! They fly, leaving their clothes behind

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Ill be so bold to take what they have left.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword;

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: For I have loaden me with many spoils,

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Using no other weapon but his name.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: SCENE II. Orleans. Within the town.

speaker: Soldier
text_entry: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, a Captain, and others

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: The day begins to break, and night is fled,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whose pitchy mantle over-veild the earth.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Here sound retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Retreat sounded

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And here advance it in the market-place,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The middle centre of this cursed town.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For every drop of blood was drawn from him,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And that hereafter ages may behold

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What ruin happend in revenge of him,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Within their chiefest temple Ill erect

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interrd:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Upon the which, that every one may read,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Shall be engraved the sack of Orleans,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The treacherous manner of his mournful death

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And what a terror he had been to France.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I muse we met not with the Dauphins grace,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Nor any of his false confederates.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: They did amongst the troops of armed men

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Leap oer the walls for refuge in the field.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Myself, as far as I could well discern

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: For smoke and dusky vapours of the night,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: When arm in arm they both came swiftly running,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: That could not live asunder day or night.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: After that things are set in order here,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Well follow them with all the power we have.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All hail, my lords! which of this princely train

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Call ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: So much applauded through the realm of France?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Here is the Talbot: who would speak with him?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With modesty admiring thy renown,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To visit her poor castle where she lies,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That she may boast she hath beheld the man

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Is it even so? Nay, then, I see our wars

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: When ladies crave to be encounterd with.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Neer trust me then; for when a world of men

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Could not prevail with all their oratory,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Yet hath a womans kindness over-ruled:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And therefore tell her I return great thanks,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And in submission will attend on her.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Will not your honours bear me company?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: No, truly; it is more than manners will:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And I have heard it said, unbidden guests

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Are often welcomest when they are gone.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Well then, alone, since theres no remedy,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I mean to prove this ladys courtesy.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Come hither, captain.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You perceive my mind?

speaker: Captain
text_entry: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Captain
text_entry: SCENE III. Auvergne. The COUNTESSs castle.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter

speaker: Captain
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Porter, remember what I gave in charge;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Madam, I will.

speaker: Porter
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Porter
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: The plot is laid: if all things fall out right,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I shall as famous be by this exploit

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus death.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And his achievements of no less account:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To give their censure of these rare reports.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Enter Messenger and TALBOT

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Madam,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: According as your ladyship desired,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And he is welcome. What! is this the man?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Madam, it is.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Is this the scourge of France?

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Is this the Talbot, so much feard abroad

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: That with his name the mothers still their babes?

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I see report is fabulous and false:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I thought I should have seen some Hercules,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: A second Hector, for his grim aspect,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf!

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Should strike such terror to his enemies.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But since your ladyship is not at leisure,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ill sort some other time to visit you.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Marry, for that shes in a wrong belief,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I go to certify her Talbots here.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Re-enter Porter with keys

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Prisoner! to whom?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To me, blood-thirsty lord;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And for that cause I trained thee to my house.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: For in my gallery thy picture hangs:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: But now the substance shall endure the like,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: That hast by tyranny these many years

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Wasted our country, slain our citizens

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Ha, ha, ha!

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Laughest thou, wretch? thy mirth shall turn to moan.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: To think that you have aught but Talbots shadow

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Whereon to practise your severity.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Why, art not thou the man?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I am indeed.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Then have I substance too.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: No, no, I am but shadow of myself:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: You are deceived, my substance is not here;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For what you see is but the smallest part

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And least proportion of humanity:

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: It is of such a spacious lofty pitch,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Your roof were not sufficient to containt.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: He will be here, and yet he is not here:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: How can these contrarieties agree?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That will I show you presently.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: How say you, madam? are you now persuaded

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: That Talbot is but shadow of himself?

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Razeth your cities and subverts your towns

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: And in a moment makes them desolate.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse:

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: And more than may be gatherd by thy shape.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath;

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: For I am sorry that with reverence

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: I did not entertain thee as thou art.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Be not dismayd, fair lady; nor misconstrue

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: The outward composition of his body.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: What you have done hath not offended me;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Nor other satisfaction do I crave,

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: But only, with your patience, that we may

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Taste of your wine and see what cates you have;

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: For soldiers stomachs always serve them well.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: COUNTESS

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: With all my heart, and think me honoured

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: To feast so great a warrior in my house.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The Temple-garden.

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: Enter the Earls of SOMERSET, SUFFOLK, and WARWICK; RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another Lawyer

speaker: OF AUVERGNE
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Within the Temple-hall we were too loud;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: The garden here is more convenient.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Then say at once if I maintaind the truth;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error?

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Faith, I have been a truant in the law,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And never yet could frame my will to it;

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And therefore frame the law unto my will.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two blades, which bears the better temper:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two horses, which doth bear him best;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But in these nice sharp quillets of the law,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: The truth appears so naked on my side

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That any purblind eye may find it out.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And on my side it is so well apparelld,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: So clear, so shining and so evident

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That it will glimmer through a blind mans eye.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Let him that is a true-born gentleman

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And stands upon the honour of his birth,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: If he suppose that I have pleaded truth,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: But dare maintain the party of the truth,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I love no colours, and without all colour

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of base insinuating flattery

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And say withal I think he held the right.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Till you conclude that he upon whose side

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: The fewest roses are croppd from the tree

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected:

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And I.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Then for the truth and plainness of the case.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Lest bleeding you do paint the white rose red

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And fall on my side so, against your will.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: If I my lord, for my opinion bleed,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And keep me on the side where still I am.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Well, well, come on: who else?

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: Unless my study and my books be false,

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: The argument you held was wrong in you:

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: To SOMERSET

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Here in my scabbard, meditating that

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For pale they look with fear, as witnessing

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: The truth on our side.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: No, Plantagenet,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Well, Ill find friends to wear my bleeding roses,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: That shall maintain what I have said is true,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Ill turn my part thereof into thy throat.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Away, away, good William de la Pole!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, by Gods will, thou wrongst him, Somerset;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Third son to the third Edward King of England:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: He bears him on the places privilege,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or durst not, for his craven heart, say thus.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: By him that made me, Ill maintain my words

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: On any plot of ground in Christendom.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: For treason executed in our late kings days?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And, by his treason, standst not thou attainted,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: My father was attached, not attainted,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Condemnd to die for treason, but no traitor;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And that Ill prove on better men than Somerset,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Were growing time once ripend to my will.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For your partaker Pole and you yourself,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Ill note you in my book of memory,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: To scourge you for this apprehension:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Look to it well and say you are well warnd.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And know us by these colours for thy foes,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Will I for ever and my faction wear,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Until it wither with me to my grave

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or flourish to the height of my degree.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Go forward and be choked with thy ambition!

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And so farewell until I meet thee next.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This blot that they object against your house

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall be wiped out in the next parliament

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Calld for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And if thou be not then created York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I will not live to be accounted Warwick.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Meantime, in signal of my love to thee,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Against proud Somerset and William Pole,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Will I upon thy party wear this rose:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Grown to this faction in the Temple-garden,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall send between the red rose and the white

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: And so will I.

speaker: Lawyer
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thanks, gentle sir.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Come, let us four to dinner: I dare say

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: This quarrel will drink blood another day.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: SCENE V. The Tower of London.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Enter MORTIMER, brought in a chair, and Gaolers

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Even like a man new haled from the rack,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: So fare my limbs with long imprisonment.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And these grey locks, the pursuivants of death,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Nestor-like aged in an age of care,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Weak shoulders, overborne with burthening grief,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And pithless arms, like to a witherd vine

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That droops his sapless branches to the ground;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Unable to support this lump of clay,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Swift-winged with desire to get a grave,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: As witting I no other comfort have.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come:

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber;

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: And answer was returnd that he will come.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Enough: my soul shall then be satisfied.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Poor gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Before whose glory I was great in arms,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: This loathsome sequestration have I had:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And even since then hath Richard been obscured,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Deprived of honour and inheritance.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But now the arbitrator of despairs,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Just death, kind umpire of mens miseries,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I would his troubles likewise were expired,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That so he might recover what was lost.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Enter RICHARD PLANTAGENET

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And in his bosom spend my latter gasp:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And now declare, sweet stem from Yorks great stock,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Why didst thou say, of late thou wert despised?

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And, in that ease, Ill tell thee my disease.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: This day, in argument upon a case,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Some words there grew twixt Somerset and me;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Among which terms he used his lavish tongue

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And did upbraid me with my fathers death:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Else with the like I had requited him.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Therefore, good uncle, for my fathers sake,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In honour of a true Plantagenet

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And for alliance sake, declare the cause

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: That cause, fair nephew, that imprisond me

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And hath detaind me all my flowering youth

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Was cursed instrument of his decease.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Discover more at large what cause that was,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I will, if that my fading breath permit

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And death approach not ere my tale be done.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Deposed his nephew Richard, Edwards son,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: The first-begotten and the lawful heir,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Of Edward king, the third of that descent:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: During whose reign the Percies of the north,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Finding his usurpation most unjust,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Endeavord my advancement to the throne:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: The reason moved these warlike lords to this

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Was, for that--young King Richard thus removed,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Leaving no heir begotten of his body--

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I was the next by birth and parentage;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: For by my mother I derived am

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From Lionel Duke of Clarence, the third son

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: To King Edward the Third; whereas he

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Being but fourth of that heroic line.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But mark: as in this haughty attempt

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: They laboured to plant the rightful heir,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: I lost my liberty and they their lives.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Long after this, when Henry the Fifth,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thy father, Earl of Cambridge, then derived

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Marrying my sister that thy mother was,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Again in pity of my hard distress

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Levied an army, weening to redeem

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And have installd me in the diadem:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: In whom the tide rested, were suppressd.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Of which, my lord, your honour is the last.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: True; and thou seest that I no issue have

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And that my fainting words do warrant death;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But yet be wary in thy studious care.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: But yet, methinks, my fathers execution

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With silence, nephew, be thou politic:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster,

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And like a mountain, not to be removed.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: But now thy uncle is removing hence:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: As princes do their courts, when they are cloyd

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: With long continuance in a settled place.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: O, uncle, would some part of my young years

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Might but redeem the passage of your age!

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good;

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Only give order for my funeral:

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: Dies

speaker: MORTIMER
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul!

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And like a hermit overpassd thy days.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And what I do imagine let that rest.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Will see his burial better than his life.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exeunt Gaolers, bearing out the body of MORTIMER

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Choked with ambition of the meaner sort:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Which Somerset hath offerd to my house:

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: I doubt not but with honour to redress;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And therefore haste I to the parliament,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Either to be restored to my blood,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Or make my ill the advantage of my good.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, EXETER, GLOUCESTER,  WARWICK, SOMERSET, and SUFFOLK; the BISHOP OF  WINCHESTER, RICHARD PLANTAGENET, and others.  GLOUCESTER offers to put up a bill; BISHOP OF WINCHESTER snatches it, and tears it

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Comest thou with deep premeditated lines,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: With written pamphlets studiously devised,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Humphrey of Gloucester? If thou canst accuse,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or aught intendst to lay unto my charge,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Do it without invention, suddenly;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As I with sudden and extemporal speech

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Presumptuous priest! this place commands my patience,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonourd me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Think not, although in writing I preferrd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That therefore I have forged, or am not able

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickedness,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy lewd, pestiferous and dissentious pranks,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As very infants prattle of thy pride.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art a most pernicious usurer,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Forward by nature, enemy to peace;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A man of thy profession and degree;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And for thy treachery, whats more manifest?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In that thou laidst a trap to take my life,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As well at London bridge as at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The king, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From envious malice of thy swelling heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, I do defy thee. Lords, vouchsafe

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: To give me hearing what I shall reply.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: If I were covetous, ambitious or perverse,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As he will have me, how am I so poor?

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or how haps it I seek not to advance

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling?

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And for dissension, who preferreth peace

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: More than I do?--except I be provoked.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: No, my good lords, it is not that offends;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: It is not that that hath incensed the duke:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: It is, because no one should sway but he;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: No one but he should be about the king;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And that engenders thunder in his breast

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And makes him roar these accusations forth.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But he shall know I am as good--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As good!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou bastard of my grandfather!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But one imperious in anothers throne?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Am I not protector, saucy priest?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And am not I a prelate of the church?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And useth it to patronage his theft.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Unreverent Gloster!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou art reverent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Rome shall remedy this.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Roam thither, then.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, see the bishop be not overborne.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Methinks my lord should be religious

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: And know the office that belongs to such.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Methinks his lordship should be humbler;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: it fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Yes, when his holy state is touchd so near.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: State holy or unhallowd, what of that?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Is not his grace protector to the king?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: [Aside]  Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue,

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Lest it be said Speak, sirrah, when you should;

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The special watchmen of our English weal,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I would prevail, if prayers might prevail,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To join your hearts in love and amity.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, what a scandal is it to our crown,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That two such noble peers as ye should jar!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Civil dissension is a viperous worm

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A noise within, Down with the tawny-coats!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What tumults this?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: An uproar, I dare warrant,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Begun through malice of the bishops men.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: A noise again, Stones! stones! Enter Mayor

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Pity the city of London, pity us!

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: The bishop and the Duke of Gloucesters men,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Forbidden late to carry any weapon,

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Have filld their pockets full of pebble stones

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And banding themselves in contrary parts

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Do pelt so fast at one anothers pate

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: That many have their giddy brains knockd out:

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Our windows are broke down in every street

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: And we for fear compelld to shut our shops.

speaker: Mayor
text_entry: Enter Serving-men, in skirmish, with bloody pates

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To hold your slaughtering hands and keep the peace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First Serving-manNay, if we be forbidden stones,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Well fall to it with our teeth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Second Serving-manDo what ye dare, we are as resolute.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Skirmish again

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You of my household, leave this peevish broil

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And set this unaccustomd fight aside.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Third Serving-manMy lord, we know your grace to be a man

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Just and upright; and, for your royal birth,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Inferior to none but to his majesty:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And ere that we will suffer such a prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So kind a father of the commonweal,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We and our wives and children all will fight

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: First Serving-manAy, and the very parings of our nails

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Begin again

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stay, stay, I say!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if you love me, as you say you do,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My sighs and tears and will not once relent?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Who should be pitiful, if you be not?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or who should study to prefer a peace.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Yield, my lord protector; yield, Winchester;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Except you mean with obstinate repulse

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You see what mischief and what murder too

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath been enacted through your enmity;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then be at peace except ye thirst for blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Compassion on the king commands me stoop;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or I would see his heart out, ere the priest

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Should ever get that privilege of me.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the duke

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath banishd moody discontented fury,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As by his smoothed brows it doth appear:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why look you still so stern and tragical?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That malice was a great and grievous sin;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And will not you maintain the thing you teach,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But prove a chief offender in the same?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Sweet king! the bishop hath a kindly gird.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For shame, my lord of Winchester, relent!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What, shall a child instruct you what to do?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee;

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See here, my friends and loving countrymen,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This token serveth for a flag of truce

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Betwixt ourselves and all our followers:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So help me God, as I dissemble not!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  So help me God, as I intend it not!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How joyful am I made by this contract!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Away, my masters! trouble us no more;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But join in friendship, as your lords have done.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: First Serving-manContent: Ill to the surgeons.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Second Serving-manAnd so will I.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Third Serving-manAnd I will see what physic the tavern affords.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt Serving-men, Mayor,  and c

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: We do exhibit to your majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick: or sweet prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if your grace mark every circumstance,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You have great reason to do Richard right;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Especially for those occasions

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At Eltham Place I told your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And those occasions, uncle, were of force:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That Richard be restored to his blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Let Richard be restored to his blood;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So shall his fathers wrongs be recompensed.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If Richard will be true, not that alone

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But all the whole inheritance I give

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That doth belong unto the house of York,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From whence you spring by lineal descent.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: Thy humble servant vows obedience

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And humble service till the point of death.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stoop then and set your knee against my foot;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, in reguerdon of that duty done,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I gird thee with the valiant sword of York:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Rise Richard, like a true Plantagenet,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And rise created princely Duke of York.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: RICHARD

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall!

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: And as my duty springs, so perish they

speaker: PLANTAGENET
text_entry: That grudge one thought against your majesty!

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York!

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: [Aside]  Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now will it best avail your majesty

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To cross the seas and to be crownd in France:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The presence of a king engenders love

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As it disanimates his enemies.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your ships already are in readiness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sennet. Flourish. Exeunt all but EXETER

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Ay, we may march in England or in France,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Not seeing what is likely to ensue.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This late dissension grown betwixt the peers

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Burns under feigned ashes of forged love

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And will at last break out into a flame:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: As festerd members rot but by degree,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: So will this base and envious discord breed.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And now I fear that fatal prophecy

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Was in the mouth of every sucking babe;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That Henry born at Monmouth should win all

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And Henry born at Windsor lose all:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: His days may finish ere that hapless time.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. France. Before Rouen.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter JOAN LA PUCELLE disguised, with four Soldiers with sacks upon their backs

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: These are the city gates, the gates of Rouen,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Through which our policy must make a breach:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Take heed, be wary how you place your words;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Talk like the vulgar sort of market men

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That come to gather money for their corn.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If we have entrance, as I hope we shall,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And that we find the slothful watch but weak,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Ill by a sign give notice to our friends,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And we be lords and rulers over Rouen;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Therefore well knock.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Knocks

speaker: Watch
text_entry: [Within]  Qui est la?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Paysans, pauvres gens de France;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.

speaker: Watch
